title: Day 79 – Natural Bridges National Monument, UT to Hite, UT
content:
We set our alarm for 6am but it was still dark so we hit snooze a bunch. Our morning feast consisted of blueberry bread, bananas, and a half a can of cold brew apiece. During a morning pee I caught a picture of the sun starting to come up behind Bear’s Ears in the east.

Tess wrote up a thank-you note to Jeff and Gila, but they emerged from their RV before we left so we thanked them in person. We made sure to get a selfie with them before we left. ”We’ll miss you,” Jeff said.

Our ride back to Route 95 was mostly up, but the scenery in the rising sun distracted us nicely.

Huge buttes rolled into view as we headed west on Route 95. Before long we were in the middle of a wide red rock canyon. The going was mostly flat or downhill and there were almost no cars, so we were really able to take it all in.


We pulled over at one point fiending for something to eat. Up ahead, a dark grey van that was pulled over ahead of us reversed towards us, the driver’s hand extended out the window, holding something in a napkin. ”What you got there?” I asked. ”Donettes!” He yelled back. We rolled up to him, and he said ”You can never have too many calories. I like to help out hikers and bikers whenever I can.” We asked what his name was. He replied, ”Mark Van Camperman,” and pulled off. He stopped a little ahead and yelled, ”Have you ever been on this road before? It’s my favorite. It only gets better!”

The magic was in the air. We were able to ride next to each other most of the way. It was the most beautiful ride of the trip so far, hands down. Mark was right, the son of a gun.

After a decent uphill to finish the day, we turned south towards the Hite Ranger Station where we’d be staying the night, and where there was a water source. The huge sheer walls of Glen Canyon surrounded us, the Henry Mountains in the background. Below, Lake Powell was dry as a bone. So much for going swimming. There was no one at the station, but there was a shady alcove with picnic tables, electrical outlets and clean bathrooms. We’d found our post-up spot for the afternoon.

Cars and RVs pulled into the station every once and a while, looking for camping (campground closed) or bathrooms. One such car was driven by Nancy and Karen, who gave us a couple big jugs of water. We called them the water angels. I very much enjoyed the cold water.

It was getting pretty hot in the afternoon sun, but in the shade it was nice and cool. We really made ourselves at home, spreading our gear out on the tables, setting up our sleeping pad and even washing up. Tess did my nails, since we were just hanging around.

I was incredibly tired, but couldn’t fall asleep. I was distracted by the periodic comings and goings of travelers using the bathroom and the dozen flies that kept buzzing around and landing on me right as I would start drifting off.

After we’d been hanging out for at least four hours, the sun was still quite hot and we had a while to wait before we could head down to the shadeless and technically closed campground. Just then, a cyclist pulled into the station. He was doing a 600+ mile mixed surface bike race in a huge loop from Moab, and had just ridden from Monticello over the San Juan Mountains. He was just looking for water and a short rest before continuing on to the Henry Mountains. A very different experience from ours. A little later, four more cyclists in the race pulled in. Despite competing against each other, they were surprisingly chill. Just hanging out, excitedly discussing the route. They hung out for a while, and we gave them some energy chews before they set off again. One guy was all spent and had decided to call his girlfriend in Salt Lake to pick him up. We were glad we had no more riding to do that day.

Finally, the sun disappeared behind the canyon wall and we relocated down to the well-kept but deserted campground. The road was blocked off to vehicles a ways up, so we knew we wouldn’t be disturbed. We were in awe of our surroundings as the stars slowly came into view. As we lay in our tent, the only sound was the high-pitched squeaking of bats. We’d hear them any time we woke up during the night until morning.
